Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Different Perspectives on Social Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social learning is the cornerstone of human culture, underlying important social processes such as spread of beliefs, social norms, and collective decision making. A number of disciplines investigate how individuals learn from each other, often asking similar questions but being unaware of promising methods and established results in other fields. For instance, conformity has been studied in evolutionary
anthropology, animal learning, statistical physics, social psychology, political science, and other fields; but there are few cross-citations between their often overlapping findings. This workshop will bring together leading researchers studying social learning within different fields. Besides theoretical integration and progress, the workshop will inform pressing current questions on the circumstances that promote or restrict social learning. Effective social learning is important for human culture, but the same processes can also lead to spread of erroneous beliefs, damaging social norms, and faulty collective decision making. Understanding the factors that promote or inhibit social learning processes also has important management implications.

Many different research communities investigate how individuals learn from each other and, consequently, how beliefs spread in societies. These communities include cognitive and social psychology, sociology and social network science, biology and animal learning, evolutionary anthropology and political science, computer science, statistical physics, organization and management science. Each of these perspectives has been extremely productive and useful, but their findings were often unnoticed in other fields. Even though they often investigate similar questions, they use different methodologies and vocabularies. The workshop will enable theoretical integration of previously disconnected strands of research on social learning in different disciplines. One promising direction is the integration between cognitive psychology, organization science, network science, and statistical physics to investigate determinants and processes supporting the emergence of collective intelligence. Another promising direction is development of new artificial learning algorithms, based on insights from theories of social influence developed in social psychology. These and other directions will be discussed and discovered during the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social learning is the cornerstone of human culture, shaping individual and group beliefs and behaviors and is essential for acquiring language, knowledge, and skills from the earliest days of life. It underlies important and ubiquitous social phenomena including formation and spread of social norms and beliefs, cooperation and coordination, group decision making and problem solving, learning and performance of organizations, political behavior and governance, and emergence of conflict and violence.  In this project we aimed to integrate the current theoretical and empirical approaches to social learning in different disciplines, ranging from psychology, evolutionary anthropology, cognitive science, social psychology, sociology, computational social science, political science, organization science, economics, biology, and behavioral ecology, to computer science,  statistical physics, and applied mathematics. Even though research goals and frameworks used in different communities are often compatible or even overlapping, their findings are not sufficiently shared. Taking an occasional stock of the current state of the field can help cross-fertilize ideas and speed up the process of scientific discovery by building on already discovered results. When cross-fertilization of ideas does occur, it can lead to important advances.

The projects and publications originating from this workshop provide further examples of such successful cross-fertilization. For example, Lee et al. (2019, Nature Human Behaviour) have integrated methods from social network theory and applied mathematics with findings from cognitive and social psychology to explain how people learn about prevailing social norms. Giannoccaro et al. (2019, Journal of Business Research), have integrated models from organizational science and statistical physics with the methods of experimental psychology to show how collective social learning and intelligence depends on network structure. Other projects under way integrate models of individual decision making and social networks to understand how teams adapt to changing choice environments, combine models of belief dynamics from statistical physics with models of learning processes from cognitive science to understand development of expertise, and combine a model of cultural evolution with the literature on radicalization and spread of beliefs on social networks, to understand the tradeoffs between covert and overt signaling of radical political ideas. Each of these projects combines and transcends two or more disciplines to understand social learning theoretically and help understand important real-world problems, such as how people discuss and spread extreme political views, how they develop biases about minority groups, what factors influence collective intelligence of teams, and how false experts can rise on online social networks.
